text.b: Abstract—Multiple MIMO (Multiple Input Multiple
Output) modes are the salient characteristics of 802.11n
wireless networks. An efficient MIMO mode switching
scheme is highly desirable for rate adaptation, which can
optimize the combination of MIMO mode and MCS
(Modulation Coding Scheme) to achieve the maximum
system throughput. In this paper, we have proposed and
verified three design guidelines for the MIMO mode
switching through real experiments. Based on these
guidelines, we then present a simple and efficient MImo
mode Switching Scheme, called MISS, and implement it into
the Atheros-based device driver. MISS uses a crossover
step-based searching algorithm to find the appropriate
MIMO mode for rate adaptation. The efficiency of MISS has
been evaluated through real experiments conducted in the
indoor environments.

i.b: Keywords: 802.11n, MIMO Mode Switching, Rate Adaptation

I
NTRODUCTION
802.11n is a new generation of wireless LAN
technology that possesses higher data rates, longer range
and more reliable coverage than previous Wi-Fi
technology. MIMO is the key physical mechanism to
achieve such gains. MIMO in 802.11n includes two
MIMO modes: spatial diversity and spatial multiplexing.
In spatial diversity, a single stream is transmitted from
each transmit antenna to improve the data reliability.
While spatial multiplexing transmits multiple independent
and separate data streams concurrently. Spatial
multiplexing can only improve throughput in MIMO
channel with good spatial structure. The Demmel
Condition Number [1]
is a good indicator of the spatial
structure of MIMO channel. However, due to the
complexity of hardware and computing overhead, there is
by far no commercial wireless network card that can
provide the Demmel Condition Number for upper
protocol layers.
The goal of rate adaptation is to maximize the
throughput by balancing the data transmission rate with
the rate of packet failure. In the legacy 802.11a/b/g
networks, rate adaptation just needs to choose the best
MCS for data transmission in an adaptive manner. But in
802.11n networks, it is required to optimize the
combination of MIMO modes and MCS to achieve the
maximum system throughput. Therefore, MIMO mode
switching is a key factor of rate adaptation in 802.11n
networks.
The existing work [2-4] mainly focuses on the rate
adaptation, but the MIMO mode switching is still much
less explored. In this paper, we present an experimental
study of MIMO mode switching in 802.11n networks. Our
experiment results reveal three design guidelines critical
to MIMO mode switching for rate adaptation in 802.11n
networks.
First, the throughput has displayed one maximal point
under DS (Double Stream) and SS (Single Stream) mode,
respectively. This result indicates that the rate adaptation
should differentiate these two MIMO modes and switch
MIMO mode under different channel condition.
Second, there is no direct correlation between SNR and
spatial structure. Higher SNR does not imply better spatial
structure. In fact, in high SNR regime, SS mode is stabler
than DS mode.
Third, in mobile scenario, the fluctuation of throughput
is relatively small in both SS mode and low rates of DS
mode, but becomes rather severe at high rates of DS mode.
The experimental results show that DS mode is much
more sensitive to wireless environment.
Based on these three guidelines, we present a simple
and efficient MImo mode Switching Scheme, called MISS,
and implement it in the Atheros-based device driver.
MISS uses a crossover step-based searching algorithm to
find the appropriate MIMO mode for rate adaptation in
802.11n networks. Further experiments show that MISS
can improve system throughput profoundly.
The rest of this paper is organized as follows. Section II
presents the detailed experiment results and design
guidelines. The design and evaluation of MISS are
provided in Section III and Section IV, respectively.
Finally, we conclude this paper in Section V.

We conducted all our experiments on a programmable
AP platform, which uses Atheros 922X MIMO chipset
and supports up to 2×3 transmit/receive antenna
configurations. Atheros 922X supports up to 130Mbps
and 300Mbps data rates for 20MHz and 40MHz channel
respectively. Our AP supports both spatial multiplexing
and spatial diversity.
Our platform has several appealing features that
facilitate our experiments on MIMO mode switching for
rate adaptation. First, it provides detailed frame trace
function, by which we can achieve various important
statistics of frame transmission indexed by rate option.
The available statistics include SNR of ACK frame,
successful transmitted frame count, and frame retry count
of ongoing transmission frame, discarded frame count,
Frame Error Ratio (FER), and so on. Second, our MIMO
mode switching scheme can be used at fixed rate or added
into the existing rate adaptation modules in the wireless
adapter driver. Third, we can manually choose the MIMO
mode.

text.i: C. Guideline #1: Two maximal points of throughput

page.text: For the legacy 802.11a/b/g networks, the rationale
behind the rate adaptation algorithms (RRAA [6], RBRA
[8], CHARM [9]) is that for a given channel condition,
throughput has only one maximal point over all rate
options. However, for the 802.11n networks, this rationale
doesn’t hold any more. Our experiments have
demonstrated that the throughput in 802.11n networks has
more than one maximal points over all rate options, but it
has only one maximal point under DS mode and SS mode,
respectively.
Fig. 2 shows the throughput curves at different
locations in experiment environment A and B. Fig. 2(a)
shows the throughput curves over all rate options. At all
locations, the throughput curves display two maximal
points. The oscillation of throughput is often visible
between common rate options of SS mode and DS mode.
For example, the throughput of P4 increases from 26DS to
39SS, but decreases from 39SS to 39DS. Fig. 2(b) and Fig.
2(c) show the throughput curves over the rate options
under DS mode and SS mode, respectively. The
throughput curve has only one maximal point under these
two modes.
The new correlation between throughput and rate has
significant implications for rate adaptation design in

lower rate option) if throughput decreases. The
underlying principle is that only one maximal point of
throughput exists over all rate options. But in 802.11n
networks, the throughput has more than one maximal
points, which requires new MIMO mode switching
scheme for rate adaption.

page.text: Fig. 3. Correlation between ACK SNR and throughput
Fig. 3 shows the correlation of ACK SNR and
throughput of P1 and P4 over three different rates.
Although the average SNR of P1 is larger than that of P4,
the average throughput of P1 is lower than that of P4 at
rate 117 and 130 Mbps. Similar results have been
observed from other places. In 802.11n networks, the
effect of spatial multiplexing is primarily determined by
spatial structure of channel, so the SNR cannot be used
as a major indicator of rate adaptation. Another
interesting finding is that the average throughput of SS
mode is higher than that of DS mode in high SNR regime.
We have chosen four different locations with similar
SNR (Fig. 1(b)). At each location, we fixed transmission
rate options at 26SS, 26DS, 39SS, 39DS, 52SS and
52DS sequentially. The average throughput of SS mode
at each of those four locations is higher than that of DS
mode (Fig. 4).

text.i: E. Guideline #3: DS mode is sensitive to wireless

page.text: The real time traces of throughput in the static and
mobile scenarios under different rate options and MIMO
modes are shown in Fig. 5. Fig. 5(a) and Fig. 5(b) show
that in SS mode and at low rate (52 Mbps) of DS mode,
the fluctuation of throughput in mobile and static
scenarios is relatively small. It becomes rather severe at
high rate (104 Mbps) of DS mode, especially in the
mobile scenarios, as shown in Fig. 5(c). The reason
behind these results is that DS mode is sensitive to both
SNR and spatial structure. In mobile scenarios, both
SNR and spatial structure are changing fast, which
causes dramatic fluctuation of throughput. Therefore, the
rate options of SS mode are more preferable than those
of DS mode with similar throughput.

Most algorithms for rate adaptation include three
stages: rate increasing, rate probing and rate decreasing.
At different stages, the algorithms need to perform
different operations to track the time-varying wireless
channel. Therefore, to match up with the rate adaptation,
MISS also performs different MIMO mode switching
methods at each stage. The details of MISS at each stage
are described as follows.
At the stage of rate increasing, MISS uses the
crossover method to switch MIMO mode. It first chooses
the neighbor rate indexes between DS mode and SS
mode in an alternative manner, such as 13SS -> 26DS ->
19.5SS -> 39DS. Then MISS compares the throughputs
and SNRs of rate points in DS mode and SS mode to
determine MIMO modes. After finding out the optimal
MIMO mode, MISS changes transmission rate or probes
rate options. The pseudo code of rate increasing is shown
in Procedure 1.

IV. E
VALUATION
In this section, we evaluate the performance of MISS
with real experiments. We implement both MISS and
Zigzag [4] MIMO mode switching methods into the rate
adaptation module Minstrel [10] of the Atheros-based
device driver. Zigzag keeps increasing transmission rate
in the same MIMO mode until no throughput
improvement, then switches MIMO mode, probes rate
options and changes transmission rate in the new MIMO
mode. On the contrary, MISS first finds the optimal
MIMO mode, and then changes transmission rate or
probes rate options.
We evaluate MISS and Zigzag in two experimental
scenarios: static and mobile (pedestrian speed). P4 is
chosen for the experiments of static scenario. In this
static scenario, there are some competitive clients and
one hidden node.
Fig. 7 shows the throughput curves of MISS and
Zigzag in static scenario. The average throughput of
MISS is higher than that of Zigzag. The reason is that
MISS keeps the accurate track of MIMO mode and
switches MIMO mode in time, in contrast, Zigzag uses
the same mode in most of the time until there is no
chance to improve the throughput. Therefore, Zigzag
consume more time to switch the MIMO mode.
Fig. 8 shows the throughput curves of MISS and
Zigzag in mobile scenario. In most of the time, the
throughput of MISS is higher than that of Zigzag, and the
average throughput is also higher than that of Zigzag.
This is expected because the spatial structure of wireless
channel changes fast in mobile scenario, and MISS can
track it to find the suitable MIMO mode. These
experiments have clearly demonstrated that MISS is a
simple and efficient scheme to find a suitable MIMO
mode for rate adaptation.

V. Conclusion
In this paper, we focus on the MIMO mode switching
for rate adaption in 802.11n wireless networks. From the
real experiments in the static, mobile and interferential
environments, we find three important design guidelines
for MIMO mode switching. Based on these guidelines,
we have proposed a simple and efficient MIMO mode
switching scheme (MISS) for rate adaption. The key
concept of MISS is to find optimal MIMO mode first,
and then to change transmission rate or probe rate
options. MISS can converge to optimal MIMO mode fast.
Experimental results show that MISS can improve
throughput significantly, especially in mobile scenario.
